title: Lavender Tallow Balm: My Weird Winter Skin Fix
body:
Okay so my face was freaking out. This was back in, I don't know, December maybe. Right when it got properly cold. Not cute holiday cold, but that dry, mean cold that makes everything crack. My skin felt like paper. Tight paper someone had crumpled up and tried to smooth back out. I was using that fancy La Mer cream my sister gave me for my birthday—the tiny jar that costs more than my electric bill—and it did nothing. Zero. Felt like I was smearing expensive water on a desert. Also tried the CeraVe stuff from the drugstore, the one in the big tub. Made my cheeks feel weird. Like there was a film. A weird film.

And my hands. God, my hands. They’d get these little splits at the knuckles. Every time I bent my fingers it was like a tiny paper cut. I was going through tubes of Neutrogena Norwegian Formula like it was going out of style. It helped for like five minutes. Then back to sandpaper.

So I’m scrolling on my phone one night, probably 11 PM, half-watching some baking show. My feet were cold. I was wrapped in this old blanket that smells like my grandma’s house. And I keep seeing this word: tallow. Beef tallow. For your skin. I thought it was a joke at first. Like, beef fat? On my face? I pictured rubbing a steak on my cheeks. It sounded gross. And medieval. But I was desperate. And curious. The algorithm had me. It showed me this Etsy shop, some small place in France making whipped tallow balm. They had a lavender one. For sleep and stuff. I was skeptical. So skeptical. But my credit card was right there. And I clicked it.

## How Beef Tallow Ended Up on My Nightstand

Look, I didn’t expect much. I ordered the Whipped Tallow Balm in lavender because I figured if my face was going to smell like a farm, at least lavender might cover it up. It arrived in this simple little jar. No crazy packaging. I opened it sitting at my kitchen table. The chair was hard. I was still in my work clothes.

First thing: smell. It didn’t smell like beef. At all. It smelled like… lavender. But not like a candle or air freshener. More like the actual plant. Like if you crushed lavender buds in your hand. A little earthy underneath. Not sweet. Just… herbal. Calm. I poked it. The texture was weird. Not bad weird. It was super soft, like it was half-melted already, but when you scoop a bit it holds its shape. Like cool butter that’s been whipped for ages. I put a tiny bit on the back of my hand. It melted. Like, immediately. No greasy film. Just gone. My skin just drank it. That was the first surprise.

I was still nervous. Putting beef fat on my face. But the logic started to make sense, reading about it while the stuff was on my hand. Tallow—this specific kind, from grass-fed cows—is apparently really similar to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum. So it doesn’t just sit on top. It sinks in. It tells your skin it can chill out on overproducing oil because the good stuff is already there. Good for dry patches, good for sensitive skin, all that. Sounded plausible. More plausible than the 50-ingredient list on my old night cream.

So that night, I washed my face. Took a little scoop. Braced myself. Rubbed it between my palms and just… patted it on. On my face, my neck, those angry knuckles on my hands.

## What Actually Happened to My Skin

I woke up the next day expecting a disaster. A breakout. A weird sheen. Something.

My face felt… normal. Not oily. Not tight. Just normal. My skin felt quiet. That’s the best word. Not screaming for moisture. My knuckles looked less red. The little cracks didn’t sting when I made a fist. That was day one.

I kept using it. Just at night. The lavender smell is actually really nice before bed. It’s not overpowering. It’s just there. On my pillow. It does make the whole routine feel more… intentional. Like a little ritual. Wash face, tallow balm, sleep. My cat tries to sniff my face when I have it on. He’s confused.

After a week, the difference wasn’t subtle. The dry, flaky patches on my cheeks were just gone. Completely. My foundation—the IT Cosmetics CC cream I’ve used for years—started applying differently. Smooth. No clinging to dry bits. My hands stopped cracking. I stopped carrying hand cream in my bag.

Here’s the weirdest part. I have this one fine line, right between my eyebrows. From squinting, I guess. I’ve had it for a couple years. It’s not deep, but it’s there. After a few weeks of this tallow balm, I swear it looks less… pronounced. Not gone. Don’t get me wrong. But softer. Like my skin was just so thirsty it was creating wrinkles from dryness, and now it’s plumped back up. I didn’t even buy it for that. I bought it so my face wouldn’t hurt.

Oh, random tangent—this reminds me of the hotel soap in Denver. The really nice, expensive hotel. The soap was fine, but it dried my hands out so bad I had to buy lotion from a CVS at 10 PM. Spent all that money on the room and the soap was trash. This tallow balm jar cost less than one night at that hotel and actually fixes the problem. Go figure.

## Would I Buy This Lavender Tallow Balm Again?

I’m almost out of my first jar. I’m definitely ordering another. I already got one for my mom, who has psoriasis on her elbows. She texted me last week saying it’s the only thing that’s calmed it down without a prescription. So that’s something.

It’s not magic. It’s not going to make you look 21 again. But if your skin is dry, or sensitive, or just pissed off at the winter, it’s a solid fix. It’s simple. One ingredient doing the work of ten. I like that. No fragrance oils, no fillers, no mystery chemicals. Just whipped beef tallow and lavender essential oil. From that little Etsy shop in France. It feels honest.

My nighttime routine is stupid simple now. Cleanse, tallow, done. I don’t miss the twelve-step process. My skin has never been happier. Or more calm. It just feels… healthy. Not “Instagram glow” healthy, but “I don’t think about my skin anymore” healthy. That’s the goal, right?

Anyway. If you’re curious about natural skincare, or you’ve tried everything for dry skin and nothing sticks, this might be worth a shot. A weird shot, but a shot. I’m a convert. My face is proof.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, surprisingly. The science-y reason is that it’s bio-similar to our own skin oils, so it absorbs deep and doesn’t just clog stuff up. It’s like giving your skin what it actually recognizes and needs, especially when it’s dry or sensitive.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Not in my experience. And I can get clogged pores easy. It melts right in. It’s not like putting Vaseline on your face. It’s more like a super nutrient-dense moisturizer that sinks in. If you’re super oily, maybe just use it at night. But for dry or combo skin, it’s been perfect.

**What does the lavender tallow balm smell like?**
It smells like real lavender. Not perfume lavender. It’s earthy and herbal and a little calming. It’s not strong all night, just a nice scent when you’re applying it. Really does make the whole thing feel like a relaxing ritual before bed.

So yeah. That’s my tallow story. My skin’s happy, I’m happy. I’ll probably order another jar next week.
random_tangent: I should probably order another jar soon
